4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early years? Bought from settlers.
Butter? From cows.
What was the price of butter? $2.50.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese? We bought small quantities ordinary in the store.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, bacon, hams, and chickens when we could get them.
How did you get fresh meat? Killed our own for winter after 20 year—beef and game.
How often did you get fresh meat? Seldom in summer.
How did you preserve meat? Frozen in winter.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized? Organized about 1900.
Did you use game? Yes, we did.
What kinds? Prairie chicken and quail.
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? We were able at times to purchase fresh caught.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh and salted was.
Kinds? Sometimes shipped in to the store.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? $2.00.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? $1.50.

What other beverages were used? Water.

Had any strong water boiled the first year?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

All kinds ordinarily after first year.

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $3.00 per bu.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Not regularly.

If not, where from? We never bought after the first year.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? 1893.

Potatoes 1893, Cabbage 1893, Carrots 1893, Onions 1893.

Turnips 1893, Beets 1893.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 400 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By box.

What weight? 20 lbs.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...

What was the price of prunes? $2.00.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

Apples, green and dried, raisins, saskatoons, chokecherries, and some wild strawberries, gooseberries, raspberries.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes, berries we picked in the woods.

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons?

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1893.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1895.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1895.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Fruit only.

To what extent? About 50 qts. each.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

17. Give a typical day's meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time, show the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast—porridge of oats, wheat or corn meal with bacon and dried apples mostly as fruit. Always milk plentifully.

Dinner—meat—always fresh in winter. Salt pork in summer with potatoes, turnips & other vegetables with some dessert.

My wife & one child 2 yrs. old in 1892.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Roast beef, mince pie, vegetables.

Sand with child and a bachelor neighbor named George Pope Clement—a brother of Judge Clement late of Vancouver.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Only for a short time in the spring of 1893. The train from Regina to Saskatoon ran twice weekly but the last train down for Regina left Saskatoon on Dec. 6, 1892. We had no other come north until Mar. 30, 1893. Some 50 men lived largely on chopped wheat in order that sick folk & children could have oatmeal and white bread.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). We always when on the farm preferred our own foods from our home grown meats and vegetables.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed). This information asked for is mostly dealt with in the foregoing replies to questions asked. One of the first great detriments to early settlement was the fact that the Canadian Pacific Railway gave a monopoly of all their cars to grain companies who would not did build elevators on their sidings. This put us settlers at the mercy of the grain dealers combine or grain exchange. It is not too much to say that we settlers were robbed of several cents a bushel on every bit of grain we sold. A farmer could not get a car at any station where an elevator had been erected. The sale of cattle also was in the hands of a monopoly headed by the Gordon Brothers Co. They never got the value of our breed. We had to keep all steers till three years old and the most we got was $1.50 for an animal that would dress 800 lbs. This along with the high freight rates and high cost of alfalfa supplies made the years of early settlement a period of poverty. It has been partly overcome by organized cooperatives. But much remains to be done, but will not be done until the political parties are cleansed by the election of men of principle.

John Evans
